subject: Design
subcategory: Design Disasters and What They Teach Us
title: Brutalist Housing: When Concrete Dreams Became Nightmares
description: A short lesson to help you apply Brutalist Housing: When Concrete Dreams Became Nightmares.

hook.text: In the 1960s, architects loved raw concrete housing towers. The residents who lived in them didn't.

buildup.text: Brutalist housing promised 'streets in the sky' â€” elevated walkways connecting tower blocks into communities.

discovery.text: In reality, walkways became windswept, stairwells became crime spots, and concrete aged into gray misery.

twist.text: Today, brutalist buildings are Instagram-famous. Architecture tourists photograph what residents endured.

climax.text: Brutalism shows that architects' visions and residents' lived experiences can be tragically different.

punchline.text: Buildings designed for the people were hated by the people.

quiz.question: Why did brutalist housing projects often fail?
options: Elevated walkways and concrete environments became hostile to residents
